Notes: Have a meeting that explains the requirements of the next assignment, what the deliverables are alongside the expectations
Describe the requirements in more detail, define every feature and functionality
Split the requirements definition into separate individual tasks that describe the required functionality.
Using the tasks in the functional analysis, create a gantt chart of the upcoming project, with tasks, milestones etc.

Research what existing libraries or frameworks exist that do or help with implementing the requirements and functionality. Things like a JSON-validation library, existing UI for creating and displaying forms, and so on

Notes: After the meeting with Sibylle/Dierick and after finalizing the requirements, take note of and choose what tech will be useful for the needs (mvp), and what should be shelved for the wants

Create a rudimentary wireframe on paper to have a better understand the structure and flow of the webapp. Given the limited scope of the webapp, I do not feel a flow-chart or UML diagram is justified.  Technically, both the "generate response" and "create a new template" are visually (UI) similar, the latter simply adds the ability to change, add or remove keys and instead of generating a json body for a request, it should generate a json schema to be saved as a template.
During the meeting with Dierick, discuss the wireframes and proposed structure
After the meeting that finalized the requirements, integrate the received feedback into a mockup in Xd, so you have an easily viewable template to work off during the coding phase
Send the mockup to Dierick/.. to get feedback, and finalize the design

Implement a functional minimal viable product. Ignore all additional "nice to have" functionality and focus on the core requirements. - load templates - generate request based on template - ability to change values of keys in the request

Resources: Andrei Lavrenov, David Dierick, Sibylle Le Roye
Notes: Plan a meeting with Sybille or Dierick so they can check the progress and if neccesary bring in desired changes

Finish implementing functionality if that wasn't done yet and make the web-app look nice and presentable, for example by implementing bootstrap to display the forms, as it's widely used and thus will be familiar to the users. Bring in any changed talked about during the feedback.

Notes: Have a meeting where you show the final implementation and functionality of the service

Expand upon the work in Sprint 1, and add the ability to change not just the keys, but the template itself.  Change: - key names - key nesting - key type (text, button, select, ...)  - if a key is required - change the default "placeholder" values - remove or add keys
